perturbation.original_text: Each Party shall obtain and maintain, for the Term (i) commercial general liability insurance with a single combined liability limit of at least $5,000,000 per occurrence, (ii) workers compensation/employer’s liability insurance with a liability limit of at least $1,000,000 per occurrence or, if greater, the statutory minimum, and (iii) “all risk” property insurance on a replacement cost basis adequate to cover all assets and business interruption Losses that a Party may suffer in connection with or arising out of this Agreement, subject to policy limits, and in the case of the policies described in clause (i) above, naming the other Party as an additional insured thereunder. Upon request, each Party shall provide the other Party a certificate of insurance as proof of insurance coverage.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party shall obtain and maintain, for the Term (i) commercial general liability insurance, (ii) workers compensation/employer’s liability insurance, and (iii) “all risk” property insurance. Upon request, each Party shall provide the other Party a certificate of insurance as proof of insurance coverage.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the specific liability limits for commercial general liability and workers compensation/employer’s liability insurance weakens the insurance requirements. Omitting the 'replacement cost basis' for property insurance reduces coverage adequacy, creating a **legal contradiction** with standard business practices and state regulations that recommend or require specific minimum coverage amounts to adequately protect against potential liabilities and property losses.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General business insurance best practices and state-specific insurance regulations

perturbation.original_text:
Section 9.3 Disclaimer. EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT, (A) NO PARTY MAKES ANY REPRESENTATIONS OR WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, WITH RESPECT TO THE MATERIALS AND SERVICES, AS APPLICABLE, PROVIDED HEREUNDER, AND ALL SUCH MATERIALS AND SERVICES, AS APPLICABLE, ARE PROVIDED ON AN “AS IS” BASIS AND (B) EACH PARTY DISCLAIMS ANY AND ALL WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING ANY IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, NON-
INFRINGEMENT OR FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 9.3 Disclaimer. EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT, (A) NO PARTY MAKES ANY REPRESENTATIONS OR WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, WITH RESPECT TO THE MATERIALS AND SERVICES, AS APPLICABLE, PROVIDED HEREUNDER, AND ALL SUCH MATERIALS AND SERVICES, AS APPLICABLE, ARE PROVIDED ON AN “AS IS” BASIS AND (B) EACH PARTY DISCLAIMS ANY AND ALL WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING ANY IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the warranty disclaimer for 'MERCHANTABILITY AND NON-INFRINGEMENT', the contract creates a **legal loophole** that contradicts the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC). This omission introduces potential liability for providing services or materials that are not fit for their ordinary purpose or infringe on intellectual property rights.

perturbation.original_text: A Provider shall not be permitted to bind a Recipient or any of its Affiliates or enter into any agreements (oral or written), contracts, leases, licenses or other documents (including the signing of checks, notes, bills of exchange or any other document, or accessing any funds from any bank accounts of Recipient or any of its Affiliates) on behalf of Recipient or any of its Affiliates except with the express prior written consent of Recipient, which consent may be given from time to time as the need arises and for such limited purposes as expressed therein.
perturbation.changed_text: A Provider shall not be permitted to bind a Recipient or any of its Affiliates or enter into any agreements (oral or written), contracts, leases, licenses or other documents on behalf of Recipient or any of its Affiliates except with the express prior written consent of Recipient.
perturbation.explanation: Removing '(including the signing of checks, notes, bills of exchange or any other document, or accessing any funds from any bank accounts of Recipient or any of its Affiliates)' creates a **legal loophole** that may violate fiduciary duty and agency laws. By omitting specifics regarding financial instruments, the clause becomes vague. The omission introduces legal risk because it fails to explicitly prevent the Provider from engaging in unauthorized financial transactions.
